expectations:
- MUST be in Spanish

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Prefer concept names over vendor names in chapter titles/descriptions (e.g., "Package management" instead of "npm"). Ecosystem-level tools (npm, yarn, Redux, Zustand) should be avoided in titles
    - Exception: foundational tools that ARE the course subject matter are allowed (e.g., "Git" in a programming course, "Node.js" in a web dev course, "Docker" in a DevOps course). The test: would a chapter about this subject be incomplete without mentioning this tool?
    - Vendor name usage is a minor issue — it affects title quality but not pedagogical content. Do NOT treat it as a major error
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add assessment-style chapters: no final projects, capstone assignments, exercises, quizzes, or "test your knowledge" chapters. A theoretical synthesis chapter (e.g., "Design Patterns in Architecture") is fine even if it synthesizes prior material — the rule targets assessment/project chapters, not synthesis of knowledge. If a chapter uses the word "capstone" but is theoretical (not an assignment), treat it as a minor issue at most, not a major error
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model E provides an exceptionally comprehensive and well-structured curriculum with 95 chapters covering chemistry from fundamentals to advanced mastery. Strengths: (1) Excellent granularity - organic chemistry is broken into many specific chapters (sustitución/eliminación, adiciones, carbonilos, ácidos carboxílicos, heterociclos, radicales, retrosíntesis, organometálicos, oxidación/reducción, protección/desprotección, síntesis asimétrica, productos naturales) which is appropriate for top-level mastery. (2) Analytical chemistry is thoroughly covered with separate chapters for principles, statistics, quimiometría, muestreo, volumetría, electroanalíticos, cromatografía, separaciones, espectroscopía atómica, aseguramiento de calidad, and metrología. (3) Includes unique and important topics like química de alimentos, toxicología química, química atmosférica, química acuática/geoquímica, biofísica estructural, química bioinorgánica, materiales electrónicos, energía y almacenamiento. (4) Good coverage of modern topics: aprendizaje automático, gestión de datos/reproducibilidad, computación científica. (5) Titles are concise and descriptions are straight to the point without filler words. (6) Logical progression from foundational to advanced. (7) Career chapter included. Minor issues: (a) Including 'Matemáticas para química' and 'Física para química' as full chapters is somewhat unusual for a chemistry course - these are prerequisites rather than chemistry content, though arguably useful. (b) Some descriptions could be slightly more concise. (c) Mentions Python/R by name in the computación científica chapter, which is a minor vendor-neutrality issue. Overall, this is the most comprehensive and well-organized curriculum.

Model B provides 53 well-structured chapters with excellent coverage. Strengths: (1) Very good balance between breadth and depth across all major chemistry subdisciplines. (2) Includes important advanced topics like fotoquímica, química supramolecular, simetría y teoría de grupos, catálisis y química de superficies, and automatización/IA en química. (3) Titles are generally concise and professional. (4) Descriptions are informative without filler words. (5) Good coverage of analytical methods with separate chapters for IR/Raman, UV-Vis, RMN, espectrometría de masas, cristalografía, separaciones, metrología, and electroanálisis. (6) Includes ethics, reproducibility, and career chapters. (7) Modern topics well-covered (automatización e IA, química de flujo). Minor issues: (a) Organic chemistry could be more granular - some chapters combine several topics (e.g., 'Alcoholes, éteres y organometálicos'). (b) Some descriptions use 'host-guest' in English rather than Spanish. (c) Missing explicit coverage of nuclear chemistry/radiochemistry, which is a notable gap. (d) Missing chemistry of food, forensic chemistry, and some applied areas. Overall, very strong curriculum with good modern coverage but a few content gaps.

Model F provides 63 chapters with very thorough coverage. Strengths: (1) Extremely detailed and comprehensive - covers nearly every major topic in chemistry. (2) Excellent coverage of physical chemistry with separate chapters for termodinámica avanzada, cinética avanzada, mecánica estadística, química cuántica, and chemistry computacional. (3) Includes many applied/specialized areas: química forense, química de alimentos, radioquímica avanzada, química de la energía, nanotecnología, química medicinal, biología molecular. (4) Good progression from basic to advanced. (5) Descriptions are generally informative and detailed. (6) Includes career development chapter. Issues: (a) Descriptions are sometimes too long and detailed, bordering on verbose (e.g., the cinética química description lists many specific subtopics). (b) Some titles are slightly verbose (e.g., 'Enlace químico: iónico, covalente y metálico', 'Estructura atómica y modelos históricos', 'Lantánidos, actínidos y elementos del bloque f'). (c) Mentions specific software names (Python, R, ChemDraw, SciFinder, Reaxys) which violates vendor neutrality. (d) Some redundancy between chapters (e.g., química ambiental and química verde are separate but have overlapping descriptions). (e) Some filler in descriptions. Despite these issues, the content coverage is excellent.

Model A provides 45 chapters with solid coverage of chemistry fundamentals through advanced topics. Strengths: (1) Clean, concise titles that follow the guidelines well. (2) Descriptions are focused and free of filler words. (3) Good logical progression from materia y medición through to desarrollo profesional. (4) Covers key areas: organic chemistry (multiple chapters), analytical chemistry, physical chemistry, materials, biochemistry, environmental, green chemistry. (5) Includes important topics like nanociencia, química computacional, chemistry verde, seguridad, and calidad. Issues: (a) Organic chemistry coverage, while adequate, is less granular than Models E or F - missing separate chapters for heterocycles, pericyclic reactions, radicals. (b) Missing nuclear chemistry/radiochemistry entirely, which is a significant gap for a comprehensive chemistry curriculum. (c) Missing química medicinal/diseño de fármacos. (d) Missing some important physical chemistry topics like mecánica estadística as a standalone topic, simetría y teoría de grupos. (e) Missing propiedades coligativas and solutions as a dedicated chapter. (f) 45 chapters is on the lower end for achieving truly comprehensive mastery-level coverage. Overall, a clean and well-organized curriculum but with notable content gaps for top-1% mastery.

Model C provides 67 chapters, the most of any model. Strengths: (1) Very comprehensive coverage across many areas. (2) Includes unique chapters on gestión de proyectos, liderazgo y mentoría, emprendimiento, búsqueda de financiación, propiedad intelectual, and diseño de infraestructuras de laboratorio. (3) Good coverage of computational chemistry with multiple chapters (simulación molecular, DFT, aplicaciones). (4) Includes modern topics like machine learning, cheminformática, and técnicas ómicas. Issues: (a) Many chapters seem overly granular in professional/soft skills areas while core chemistry topics are sometimes combined (e.g., 'Estructura atómica y tabla periódica' as one chapter, 'Enlace químico y teoría de orbitales' as one chapter). (b) The final chapter 'Plan de maestría profesional y trayectoria hacia la excelencia' sounds like a synthesis/capstone chapter with language that hints at the 'top 1%' instruction ('excelencia', 'nivel experto'). (c) Some titles are verbose or contain filler (e.g., 'Química y física de la luz (fotones, fotoquímica y fotofísica)', 'Transición a la carrera profesional y desarrollo profesional'). (d) Having two career chapters plus leadership, mentoring, entrepreneurship, and funding chapters is excessive for a chemistry course. (e) Some descriptions use filler-like language. (f) Missing some core topics or combining them too aggressively (e.g., no separate estequiometría foundational treatment, gases are not covered as a standalone chapter). (g) The balance between professional skills chapters and core chemistry content is off. Overall, while comprehensive in scope, the curriculum suffers from poor balance and some guideline violations.

Model D provides 45 chapters with reasonable coverage. Strengths: (1) Good foundational progression - starts well with clear basics and builds up. (2) Includes nomenclatura inorgánica as a dedicated chapter, which is useful for beginners. (3) Clean structure with logical ordering. (4) Covers most major areas of chemistry. Issues: (a) Some titles are verbose (e.g., 'Tabla periódica y propiedades periódicas', 'Hidrocarburos y reacciones orgánicas fundamentales'). (b) Organic chemistry coverage is relatively sparse - only about 6 dedicated chapters, missing important subtopics like enolates in detail, specific heterocycle chemistry depth, pericyclic reactions. (c) Missing simetría y teoría de grupos, which is essential for advanced chemistry mastery. (d) Missing fotoquímica as a standalone topic. (e) Missing mecánica estadística. (f) Missing catálisis as focused advanced topic (only mentioned briefly within cinética). (g) Some descriptions contain filler words (e.g., 'Fundamentos del descubrimiento de fármacos'). (h) Mentions specific vendor tools (ChemDraw, SciFinder, Reaxys, Python, R) violating vendor neutrality. (i) Analytical chemistry coverage is adequate but not as granular as top models. (j) 45 chapters is insufficient for truly comprehensive mastery-level coverage given the breadth of chemistry. Overall, a decent curriculum but lacking the depth and comprehensiveness needed for mastery level.

Model G provides only 41 chapters, which is the fewest of all models. Strengths: (1) Titles are generally concise. (2) Logical progression from basics to advanced. (3) Covers main areas of chemistry. Issues: (a) Significantly less comprehensive than other models - many important topics are missing or barely covered. (b) Missing key advanced topics: mecánica estadística, simetría y teoría de grupos, fotoquímica, química supramolecular, catálisis avanzada, química medicinal, química de alimentos, química nuclear avanzada, nanotecnología as detailed coverage. (c) Organic chemistry is particularly sparse - only about 6 chapters, missing enolatos, ácidos carboxílicos in depth, retrosíntesis, síntesis asimétrica, productos naturales, organometálicos en síntesis. (d) Analytical chemistry coverage is minimal - only 3 chapters. (e) Physical chemistry is underrepresented. (f) Biochemistry is condensed into a single chapter. (g) Missing computational chemistry depth, data science/ML. (h) Some titles could be more specific (e.g., 'Oxigenados Orgánicos' is vague, 'Sustancias Aromáticas' is unusual terminology). (i) Missing propiedad intelectual, gestión de datos/reproducibilidad. (j) Career chapter description is too brief. (k) Not adequate for top-1% mastery - too many gaps in coverage. Overall, this is the least comprehensive curriculum and would not prepare someone for mastery in chemistry.

Model E provides an exceptionally comprehensive and granular curriculum (84 chapters) that perfectly captures the journey from absolute beginner to the top 1% in Chemistry. It uniquely includes foundational chapters on the necessary math and physics required for advanced chemistry, which is crucial for a learner starting with 'no prior knowledge'. It explores every major sub-discipline in extreme depth and includes modern skills like machine learning, scientific computing, data reproducibility, and intellectual property. The formatting is flawless, and it strictly avoids fluff and assessment chapters.

Model C is also outstanding (65 chapters) and highly aligned with the prompt's instruction to prepare the learner to 'lead very complex projects'. It contains incredibly detailed technical modules and stands out for its extensive coverage of professional and leadership skills, such as project management, mentoring, grant writing, intellectual property, and entrepreneurship in chemistry. It strictly follows all formatting and tone constraints.

Model F offers a highly detailed and robust curriculum (65 chapters) that includes diverse specializations such as forensic chemistry, food chemistry, bioinorganic chemistry, and programming for chemists. It scales perfectly from foundational concepts to advanced, job-ready, and research-level applications. Titles and descriptions are clean, concise, and fluff-free.

Model B provides a superb, well-structured curriculum (52 chapters) that thoroughly covers theoretical, practical, and advanced chemistry concepts. It integrates modern trends like AI and automation in chemistry and emphasizes scientific literacy and sustainability. It follows all instructions perfectly, though it is slightly less granular than Models E, C, and F.

Model A delivers a very strong and traditional chemistry curriculum (46 chapters) that would match an excellent university degree. It includes a career chapter and follows all constraints perfectly. However, it lacks the extreme depth and modern, specialized peripheral skills (like cheminformatics, deep AI integration, or advanced leadership) found in the higher-scoring models to truly push a learner into the top 1%.

Model D provides a curriculum similar in scope and depth to Model A (45 chapters). It is well-organized, fluff-free, and covers all standard undergraduate and graduate chemistry topics, including digital tools and career preparation. It misses some of the extreme granularity and cutting-edge topics present in the top models.

Model G follows all instructions, including formatting rules, negative constraints, and the inclusion of a career chapter. However, with only 41 chapters, it groups many advanced concepts together and does not reach the same level of exhaustive detail and modern technological integration as the other models. It is a very good standard curriculum, but less suited for the 'top 1% / PhD readiness' constraint compared to the rest.

Cobertura extraordinariamente amplia y moderna (quimiometría, metrología, automatización/LIMS, ML, energía, toxicología, química atmosférica/acuática, organometálica, bioinorgánica, superficies/nano, PI y carrera). Mantiene títulos concisos y descripciones mayormente sin relleno; buena progresión desde fundamentos (incluye matemáticas/física) hasta temas de frontera y práctica profesional (seguridad de procesos, regulación, reproducibilidad). Muy alineado con “dominio total” y tendencias actuales sin volverse dependiente de vendors (aunque aparece LIMS).

Muy completo y bien estructurado, con excelente profundidad en analítica (espectroscopías separadas, cristalografía, separaciones, metrología), fisicoquímica, orgánica avanzada, materiales, supramolecular, fotoquímica, y un capítulo explícito de automatización/IA. Incluye carrera, ética y reproducibilidad. Le falta algo de amplitud “industrial/práctica” que E cubre mejor (p. ej., más sobre metrología/trazabilidad a nivel sistema, muestreo, procesos detallados), pero en general es sobresaliente y moderno.

Extremadamente extenso y orientado a desempeño profesional/liderazgo (gestión de proyectos, mentoría, financiación, transferencia tecnológica, emprendimiento, data science/ML, reproducibilidad). Buena cobertura de química avanzada (materiales electrónicos, ómicas, microreactores/alto rendimiento). Debilidades: progresión inicial no asume tan bien “cero” (arranca directo con estructura atómica), algunos títulos/descripciones son más verbosos y aparece mezcla de idiomas (“Machine learning”, “best practices”), y hay capítulos algo meta/estilo ‘plan de maestría’ menos contenidos disciplinares. Aun así, muy fuerte.

Currículo sólido, coherente y bastante completo en tronco (general/orgánica/inorgánica/analítica/fisicoquímica/materiales/ambiental/verde/industrial/seguridad/calidad/comunicación/carrera). Buen nivel para estudios avanzados. Gaps frente a los mejores: menos temas de frontera (supramolecular, fotoquímica avanzada, teoría de grupos, química nuclear explícita, automatización/IA/quimiometría/reproducibilidad), y menos detalle en instrumentación/estadística moderna y química de energía.

Muy completo y profundo (incluye mecánica estadística, teoría de grupos, métodos post-HF/DFT, organometálica, bioinorgánica, forense, alimentos, energía). Buena progresión desde nociones básicas. Penalizaciones: varias descripciones usan relleno tipo “Definición de…”, y aparecen nombres de herramientas/lenguajes específicos (Python, R) y bases de datos; algunas descripciones se vuelven largas tipo lista. Aun así, cobertura disciplinar fuerte.

Cobertura amplia y ordenada para un plan universitario general con orgánica, analítica, materiales, nuclear, ambiental, catálisis, computacional, seguridad y carrera. Pero menos “top” que los anteriores: falta mayor profundidad en fisicoquímica avanzada (mecánica estadística, superficies, fotoquímica, teoría de grupos), tendencias modernas (automatización/IA, quimiometría), y capítulos de reproducibilidad/datos. Incluye vendors concretos (ChemDraw, SciFinder, Reaxys) en títulos/descripciones, contra la neutralidad.

Adecuado como esquema de química general + orgánica/analítica básica, con algunos temas avanzados (materiales, cuántica avanzada). Sin embargo, es mucho menos extenso y profundo que lo requerido para maestría/PhD: faltan computacional moderna, quimiometría/estadística seria, superficies/supramolecular/fotoquímica, procesos y seguridad de procesos con más detalle, reproducibilidad, y tendencias (automatización/IA).
